questions.question: A fall in GFR activates JG cells to release:
questions.explanation: A fall in GFR can activate the JG cells to release renin which can stimulate the glomerular blood flow and thereby the GFR back to normal. (NCERT Page 209)

questions.question: What percentage of the filtrate is reabsorbed by the renal tubules?
questions.explanation: A comparison of volume of filtrate formed per day (180 litres) with that of urine released (1.5 litres), suggests that nearly 99 per cent of the filtrate has to be reabsorbed by the renal tubules. (NCERT Page 209)

questions.question: JGA is formed by cellular modifications in:
options: Loop of Henle and vasa recta
questions.explanation: JGA is a special sensitive region formed by cellular modifications in the distal convoluted tubule and the afferent arteriole at the location of their contact. (NCERT Page 209)

questions.question: During glomerular filtration, which component of blood does NOT pass into the Bowman's capsule?
questions.explanation: Blood is filtered so finely through the glomerular membranes that almost all the constituents of the plasma except the proteins pass onto the lumen of the Bowman's capsule. (NCERT Page 208)

questions.question: The functional unit of kidney is:
questions.explanation: Each kidney has nearly one million complex tubular structures called nephrons, which are the functional units of the kidney. (NCERT Page 207)

questions.question: Glomerulus is formed by:
questions.explanation: Glomerulus is a tuft of capillaries formed by the afferent arteriole - a fine branch of renal artery. Blood from the glomerulus is carried away by an efferent arteriole. (NCERT Page 207)

questions.question: GFR in a healthy individual is approximately:
questions.explanation: GFR in a healthy individual is approximately 125 ml/minute, i.e., 180 litres per day! (NCERT Page 209)

questions.question: After hemodialysis, which substance is added to blood before returning it to the body?
questions.explanation: The cleared blood is pumped back to the body through a vein after adding anti-heparin to it. (NCERT Page 214)

questions.question: The human excretory system consists of:
options: A pair of kidneys, ureters, urinary bladder, and urethra
A pair of kidneys and urinary bladder only
Two pairs of kidneys and urethra
A kidney, two ureters, and urethra
questions.explanation: In humans, the excretory system consists of a pair of kidneys, one pair of ureters, a urinary bladder, and a urethra. (NCERT Page 206)

questions.question: ANF causes:
questions.explanation: ANF can cause vasodilation (dilation of blood vessels) and thereby decrease the blood pressure. (NCERT Page 212)

questions.question: Which of the following is the most toxic nitrogenous waste?
questions.explanation: Ammonia is the most toxic form of nitrogenous waste and requires large amounts of water for its elimination. Uric acid is the least toxic and can be removed with minimum loss of water. (NCERT Page 205)

questions.question: The broad funnel shaped space inner to the hilum of kidney with projections called calyces is:
questions.explanation: Inner to the hilum is a broad funnel shaped space called the renal pelvis with projections called calyces. (NCERT Page 206)

questions.question: Filtration slits or slit pores are found in:
questions.explanation: The epithelial cells of Bowman's capsule called podocytes are arranged in an intricate manner so as to leave some minute spaces called filtration slits or slit pores. (NCERT Page 208)

questions.question: In mammals, ammonia produced by metabolism is converted into urea in the:
questions.explanation: In ureotelic animals like mammals, ammonia produced by metabolism is converted into urea in the liver and released into the blood which is filtered and excreted out by the kidneys. (NCERT Page 205)

questions.question: The region of nephron where reabsorption is minimum is:
options: Descending limb of loop of Henle
Ascending limb of loop of Henle
questions.explanation: Henle's Loop: Reabsorption is minimum in its ascending limb. (NCERT Page 209)

questions.question: Malpighian tubules are the excretory structures of:
questions.explanation: Malpighian tubules are the excretory structures of most of the insects including cockroaches. They help in the removal of nitrogenous wastes and osmoregulation. (NCERT Page 206)

questions.question: Our lungs remove approximately how much CO2 per minute?
questions.explanation: Our lungs remove large amounts of CO2 (approximately 200mL/minute) and also significant quantities of water every day. (NCERT Page 213)

questions.question: Which segment of nephron allows passage of small amounts of urea into medullary interstitium?
questions.explanation: The collecting duct allows passage of small amounts of urea into the medullary interstitium to keep up the osmolarity. (NCERT Page 210)

questions.question: In hemodialysis, which anticoagulant is added to blood?
questions.explanation: Blood drained from a convenient artery is pumped into a dialysing unit after adding an anticoagulant like heparin. (NCERT Page 213)

questions.question: What percentage of electrolytes and water are reabsorbed by PCT?
questions.explanation: Nearly all of the essential nutrients, and 70-80 per cent of electrolytes and water are reabsorbed by the PCT segment. (NCERT Page 209)

questions.question: The collecting duct extends from:
options: Cortex to inner parts of medulla
questions.explanation: The collecting duct - this long duct extends from the cortex of the kidney to the inner parts of the medulla. (NCERT Page 210)

questions.question: Each kidney has nearly how many nephrons?
questions.explanation: Each kidney has nearly one million complex tubular structures called nephrons, which are the functional units. (NCERT Page 207)

questions.question: Tubular secretion helps in the maintenance of:
options: Ionic and acid-base balance of body fluids
questions.explanation: Tubular secretion is an important step in urine formation as it helps in the maintenance of ionic and acid-base balance of body fluids. (NCERT Page 209)

questions.question: The three main processes involved in urine formation are:
questions.explanation: Urine formation involves three main processes namely, glomerular filtration, reabsorption and secretion, that takes place in different parts of the nephron. (NCERT Page 208)

questions.question: The renal columns called Columns of Bertini are:
options: Cortex extending between the medullary pyramids
questions.explanation: The cortex extends in between the medullary pyramids as renal columns called Columns of Bertini. (NCERT Page 207)

questions.question: Antennal glands or green glands perform excretory function in:
questions.explanation: Antennal glands or green glands perform the excretory function in crustaceans like prawns. (NCERT Page 206)

questions.question: On an average, how much urea is excreted out per day?
questions.explanation: On an average, 25-30 gm of urea is excreted out per day. (NCERT Page 213)

questions.question: The osmolarity gradient in the kidney is mainly caused by:
questions.explanation: The osmolarity gradient (300-1200 mOsmolL-1) in the kidney is mainly caused by NaCl and urea. (NCERT Page 211)

questions.question: Glomerulus along with Bowman's capsule is called:
questions.explanation: Glomerulus along with Bowman's capsule is called the Malpighian body or renal corpuscle. (NCERT Page 207)

questions.question: The double walled cup-like structure which encloses the glomerulus is called:
questions.explanation: The renal tubule begins with a double walled cup-like structure called Bowman's capsule, which encloses the glomerulus. (NCERT Page 207)

questions.question: Which group of animals are uricotelic?
questions.explanation: Reptiles, birds, land snails, and insects excrete nitrogenous wastes as uric acid in the form of pellet or paste with minimum loss of water and are called uricotelic animals. (NCERT Page 205)

questions.question: The counter current mechanism is facilitated by the special arrangement of:
questions.explanation: The transport of substances facilitated by the special arrangement of Henle's loop and vasa recta is called the counter current mechanism. (NCERT Page 211)

questions.question: Normal urine is:
questions.explanation: The urine formed is a light yellow coloured watery fluid which is slightly acidic (pH-6.0) and has a characteristic odour. (NCERT Page 213)

questions.question: Animals that excrete ammonia as their primary nitrogenous waste are called:
questions.explanation: Ammonotelic animals excrete ammonia as their primary nitrogenous waste. Many bony fishes, aquatic amphibians, and aquatic insects are ammonotelic in nature. (NCERT Page 205)

questions.question: Human kidneys can produce urine nearly how many times concentrated than the initial filtrate?
questions.explanation: Human kidneys can produce urine nearly four times concentrated than the initial filtrate formed. (NCERT Page 212)

questions.question: The blood vessel that carries blood INTO the glomerulus is:
questions.explanation: Glomerulus is a tuft of capillaries formed by the afferent arteriole. Blood from the glomerulus is carried away by an efferent arteriole. (NCERT Page 207)

questions.question: The pH of normal urine is approximately:
questions.explanation: The urine formed is a light yellow coloured watery fluid which is slightly acidic (pH-6.0). (NCERT Page 213)

questions.question: ADH facilitates:
options: Water reabsorption from latter parts of tubule
questions.explanation: ADH facilitates water reabsorption from latter parts of the tubule, thereby preventing diuresis. (NCERT Page 212)

questions.question: Conditional reabsorption of Na+ and water takes place in:
questions.explanation: Conditional reabsorption of Na+ and water takes place in the DCT segment. (NCERT Page 209)

questions.question: The functioning of kidneys is regulated by hormonal feedback mechanisms involving:
questions.explanation: The functioning of the kidneys is efficiently monitored and regulated by hormonal feedback mechanisms involving the hypothalamus, JGA and to a certain extent, the heart. (NCERT Page 212)

questions.question: ADH is released from:
questions.explanation: Osmoreceptors stimulate the hypothalamus to release antidiuretic hormone (ADH) or vasopressin from the neurohypophysis. (NCERT Page 212)

questions.question: Another name for ADH is:
questions.explanation: Osmoreceptors stimulate the hypothalamus to release antidiuretic hormone (ADH) or vasopressin from the neurohypophysis. (NCERT Page 212)

questions.question: Presence of glucose in urine is called:
questions.explanation: Presence of glucose (Glycosuria) and ketone bodies (Ketonuria) in urine are indicative of diabetes mellitus. (NCERT Page 213)

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a function of nephridia?
questions.explanation: Nephridia help to remove nitrogenous wastes and maintain a fluid and ionic balance. They do not produce hormones. (NCERT Page 206)

questions.question: PCT helps maintain pH and ionic balance by secreting:
questions.explanation: PCT also helps to maintain the pH and ionic balance of body fluids by selective secretion of hydrogen ions and ammonia into the filtrate and by absorption of HCO3- from it. (NCERT Page 209)

questions.question: The epithelial cells of Bowman's capsule are called:
questions.explanation: The epithelial cells of Bowman's capsule called podocytes are arranged in an intricate manner so as to leave some minute spaces called filtration slits or slit pores. (NCERT Page 208)

questions.question: Liver secretes bile containing:
options: Bilirubin, biliverdin, cholesterol, degraded steroid hormones, vitamins and drugs
questions.explanation: Liver secretes bile-containing substances like bilirubin, biliverdin, cholesterol, degraded steroid hormones, vitamins and drugs. (NCERT Page 213)

questions.question: The notch on the inner concave surface of the kidney through which ureter, blood vessels, and nerves enter is called:
questions.explanation: Towards the centre of the inner concave surface of the kidney is a notch called hilum through which ureter, blood vessels, and nerves enter. (NCERT Page 206)

questions.question: Which substances are actively reabsorbed in the nephron?
questions.explanation: Substances like glucose, amino acids, Na+, etc., in the filtrate are reabsorbed actively whereas the nitrogenous wastes are absorbed by passive transport. (NCERT Page 209)

questions.question: Vasa recta is:
options: A minute vessel running parallel to Loop of Henle forming a U-shape
questions.explanation: A minute vessel of the peritubular capillary network runs parallel to the Henle's loop forming a 'U' shaped vasa recta. (NCERT Page 208)

questions.question: Vasa recta is absent or highly reduced in:
questions.explanation: Vasa recta is absent or highly reduced in cortical nephrons. (NCERT Page 208)

questions.question: Juxta medullary nephrons have:
options: Loop of Henle in cortex only
Very long loop of Henle that runs deep into medulla
questions.explanation: In juxta medullary nephrons, the loop of Henle is very long and runs deep into the medulla. (NCERT Page 208)

questions.question: JGA stands for:
questions.explanation: JGA is Juxta Glomerular Apparatus - a special sensitive region formed by cellular modifications in the distal convoluted tubule and the afferent arteriole at the location of their contact. (NCERT Page 209)

questions.question: Dialysing fluid has the same composition as plasma except:
questions.explanation: The dialysing fluid has the same composition as that of plasma except the nitrogenous wastes. As nitrogenous wastes are absent in the dialysing fluid, these substances freely move out. (NCERT Page 214)

questions.question: For kidney transplantation, donor is preferably a close relative to:
options: Minimise chances of rejection by immune system
questions.explanation: A functioning kidney is used in transplantation from a donor, preferably a close relative, to minimise its chances of rejection by the immune system of the host. (NCERT Page 214)

questions.question: Angiotensin II is a powerful:
questions.explanation: Angiotensin II, being a powerful vasoconstrictor, increases the glomerular blood pressure and thereby GFR. (NCERT Page 212)

questions.question: Glomerulonephritis is:
questions.explanation: Glomerulonephritis: Inflammation of glomeruli of kidney. (NCERT Page 214)

questions.question: The ultimate method for correction of acute renal failures is:
questions.explanation: Kidney transplantation is the ultimate method in the correction of acute renal failures (kidney failure). (NCERT Page 214)

questions.question: The blood vessel that carries blood OUT of the glomerulus is:
questions.explanation: Blood from the glomerulus is carried away by an efferent arteriole. (NCERT Page 207)

questions.question: As concentrated filtrate passes upward through ascending limb, it gets diluted due to:
options: Passage of electrolytes to medullary fluid
questions.explanation: As the concentrated filtrate passes upward through the ascending limb, it gets diluted due to the passage of electrolytes to the medullary fluid. (NCERT Page 209)

questions.question: Aldosterone causes reabsorption of:
options: Na+ and water from distal parts of tubule
questions.explanation: Aldosterone causes reabsorption of Na+ and water from the distal parts of the tubule. This also leads to an increase in blood pressure and GFR. (NCERT Page 212)

questions.question: Renal calculi are:
questions.explanation: Renal calculi: Stone or insoluble mass of crystallised salts (oxalates, etc.) formed within the kidney. (NCERT Page 214)

questions.question: ANF is released from:
questions.explanation: An increase in blood flow to the atria of the heart can cause the release of Atrial Natriuretic Factor (ANF). (NCERT Page 212)

questions.question: The osmolarity gradient in the kidney interstitium ranges from:
questions.explanation: The proximity between Henle's loop and vasa recta helps in maintaining an increasing osmolarity towards inner medullary interstitium, i.e., from 300 mOsmolL-1 in cortex to about 1200 mOsmolL-1 in inner medulla. (NCERT Page 211)

questions.question: Which part of nephron is lined by brush border epithelium?
questions.explanation: PCT is lined by simple cuboidal brush border epithelium which increases the surface area for reabsorption. (NCERT Page 209)

questions.question: The process of release of urine is called:
questions.explanation: The process of release of urine is called micturition and the neural mechanisms causing it is called the micturition reflex. (NCERT Page 213)

questions.question: The descending limb of loop of Henle is:
options: Impermeable to water but permeable to electrolytes
Permeable to water but almost impermeable to electrolytes
Impermeable to both water and electrolytes
questions.explanation: The descending limb of loop of Henle is permeable to water but almost impermeable to electrolytes. This concentrates the filtrate as it moves down. (NCERT Page 209)

questions.question: Glomerular filtration is considered as a process of:
questions.explanation: Blood is filtered so finely through the membranes that almost all constituents of plasma except proteins pass into Bowman's capsule. Therefore, it is considered as a process of ultra filtration. (NCERT Page 208)

questions.question: Nephrons with short loop of Henle that extends only slightly into the medulla are called:
questions.explanation: In majority of nephrons, the loop of Henle is too short and extends only very little into the medulla. Such nephrons are called cortical nephrons. (NCERT Page 208)

questions.question: Peritubular capillaries are formed from:
questions.explanation: The efferent arteriole emerging from the glomerulus forms a fine capillary network around the renal tubule called the peritubular capillaries. (NCERT Page 208)

questions.question: Each kidney of an adult human measures approximately:
questions.explanation: Each kidney of an adult human measures 10-12 cm in length, 5-7 cm in width, 2-3 cm in thickness with an average weight of 120-170 g. (NCERT Page 206)

questions.question: Angiotensin II activates which gland to release aldosterone?
questions.explanation: Angiotensin II also activates the adrenal cortex to release Aldosterone. (NCERT Page 212)

questions.question: The dialysing unit in hemodialysis contains:
options: Coiled cellophane tube surrounded by dialysing fluid
questions.explanation: The unit contains a coiled cellophane tube surrounded by a fluid (dialysing fluid) having the same composition as that of plasma except the nitrogenous wastes. (NCERT Page 213-214)

questions.question: An adult human excretes, on an average, how much urine per day?
questions.explanation: An adult human excretes, on an average, 1 to 1.5 litres of urine per day. (NCERT Page 213)

questions.question: ANF mechanism acts as a check on:
questions.explanation: ANF mechanism, therefore, acts as a check on the renin-angiotensin mechanism. (NCERT Page 212)

questions.question: The Renin-Angiotensin mechanism helps to:
questions.explanation: The Renin-Angiotensin mechanism increases glomerular blood pressure and thereby GFR through vasoconstriction by angiotensin II and increased Na+ and water reabsorption by aldosterone. (NCERT Page 212)

questions.question: The ascending limb of loop of Henle is:
options: Impermeable to water but allows transport of electrolytes
Permeable to both water and electrolytes
Permeable to water but impermeable to electrolytes
Impermeable to both water and electrolytes
questions.explanation: The ascending limb is impermeable to water but allows transport of electrolytes actively or passively. (NCERT Page 209)

questions.question: The amount of filtrate formed by the kidneys per minute is called:
questions.explanation: The amount of the filtrate formed by the kidneys per minute is called glomerular filtration rate (GFR). (NCERT Page 209)

questions.question: Sweat produced by sweat glands contains:
options: NaCl, small amounts of urea, lactic acid
questions.explanation: Sweat produced by the sweat glands is a watery fluid containing NaCl, small amounts of urea, lactic acid, etc. (NCERT Page 213)

questions.question: Accumulation of urea in blood due to malfunctioning of kidneys is called:
questions.explanation: Malfunctioning of kidneys can lead to accumulation of urea in blood, a condition called uremia, which is highly harmful and may lead to kidney failure. (NCERT Page 213)

questions.question: Blood filtered by the kidneys per minute constitutes roughly what fraction of cardiac output?
questions.explanation: 1100-1200 ml of blood filtered by the kidneys per minute constitute roughly 1/5th of the blood pumped out by each ventricle of the heart in a minute. (NCERT Page 208)

questions.question: Presence of ketone bodies in urine is called:
questions.explanation: Presence of glucose (Glycosuria) and ketone bodies (Ketonuria) in urine are indicative of diabetes mellitus. (NCERT Page 213)

questions.question: Renin converts angiotensinogen to:
questions.explanation: A fall in GFR activates JG cells to release renin which converts angiotensinogen in blood to angiotensin I and further to angiotensin II. (NCERT Page 212)

questions.question: Protonephridia or flame cells are the excretory structures in:
questions.explanation: Protonephridia or flame cells are the excretory structures in Platyhelminthes (Flatworms like Planaria), rotifers, some annelids, and the cephalochordate Amphioxus. (NCERT Page 206)

questions.question: Sebaceous glands eliminate substances like:
questions.explanation: Sebaceous glands eliminate certain substances like sterols, hydrocarbons and waxes through sebum. (NCERT Page 213)

questions.question: Which organs other than kidneys help in excretion?
questions.explanation: Other than the kidneys, lungs, liver and skin also help in the elimination of excretory wastes. (NCERT Page 213)

questions.question: The correct sequence of parts in a nephron is:
options: Bowman's capsule → DCT → Loop of Henle → PCT → Collecting duct
PCT → Bowman's capsule → Loop of Henle → DCT → Collecting duct
Bowman's capsule → PCT → Loop of Henle → DCT → Collecting duct
Bowman's capsule → Loop of Henle → PCT → DCT → Collecting duct
questions.explanation: The correct sequence is: Bowman's capsule → Proximal Convoluted Tubule (PCT) → Loop of Henle → Distal Convoluted Tubule (DCT) → Collecting duct. (NCERT Page 207-208)

questions.question: On average, how much blood is filtered by the kidneys per minute?
questions.explanation: On an average, 1100-1200 ml of blood is filtered by the kidneys per minute which constitute roughly 1/5th of the blood pumped out by each ventricle of the heart in a minute. (NCERT Page 208)
